They are about progress and ensuring that our future is in the hands of those who will inherit it — the young. Older generations have had their time to lead, to build, and to benefit from the systems we now live under. They’ve had decades, even lifetimes, to make the most of their opportunities. It's time we shift the focus to the next generation, who are entering a world that is increasingly unaffordable, unstable, and unresponsive to their needs.

That means restructuring healthcare to prioritize prevention and efficiency over costly, end-of-life treatments. It means rethinking political representation to give young voices a louder and more decisive role in shaping the future.

This is not about age discrimination — it’s about intergenerational justice. The young are the ones who will live with the consequences of our decisions. We owe it to them to create a system that works for them, not one that clings to the past for the sake of a few. If that means unsettling some older citizens, then so be it. The future cannot wait for the old to let go.
